pros: Growth within the company is encouraged
cons: None at all , great job

pros:
West allows for upward momentum for employees that apply themselves and are clear about their goals. In the 3.5 years that I have been here, I have had 2 major promotions and now make $10 more per hour than I did when I started. West appreciates smart, hard-working individuals and both of my promotions were given to me over people with more seniority who lacked the same drive. Despite that, I have only worked more than 45 hrs/week on a couple of occasions in 3 years. Overtime is not an expectation for success.

I have also been given opportunities to explore different interests and areas within the company so that I don't get bored and I continue growing and learning.

My immediate team and management here in Portland are very friendly and down-to-earth. They are very understanding of life events and do their best to help their employees in and outside their work.

We get a fair amount of PTO. Benefits are decent, if not spectacular.
cons:
West gets bogged down by bureaucracy. Once you get outside of my section of the company, it gets much more difficult to make changes, even if they seem obvious and have been "in the works" for years.

West is a large company and it is not uncommon to feel that you are just one cog in a machine.

Upper management has a tendency to make changes to benefits or programs and spin them to appear like positive changes, but which actually harm employees. The company has made 3 major acquisitions/mergers in the 3 years that I've been here (along with many small changes) and this has resulted in promises and policies made by the company not being honored down the line because the management team or our priorities have changed.

They do seem like they are doing better lately, but take everything you hear from the top levels of management with a grain of salt.

Also, sometimes work can be uneven. Overwhelming one week and very slow the next. Luckily, Christmastime and summer are the slowest seasons for my team.
advice_to_mgmt: Work for better communication and connection between different levels of the company and work to make the changes that matter to your employees, rather than just the ones that matter to the company's bottom line. Different sections of the company feel very disconnected and yet they are affected by changes within the global company with little warning and no say.

pros: Lower management was great. Incentives if you do well.
cons: Trainer was ineffective- spent too much time on personal anecdotes that were irrelevant. Company also was too quick to bend to their client without realizing how their business/front line reps would be affected. Communication from top to bottom was poor, resulting in violations in policy.

cons:
Too long to list here... micro manager if you end up in the west coast for healthcare. A manager was demoted then promoted again after someone left, zero clue how to lead a team. Managers are so anal they have alerts setup when you are away from the computer for more than 5 mins, West is the definition of Big Brother. Company itself is owned by giant PE firm, you are a number and many rifts have taken place in the last year. Too many good sales people were let go.

The CRM is not Salesforce or any other modern CRM but some Microsoft version from 2007...not kidding its really that terrible. Every process here has taken a 10 year step back.

But worst of all are the leads or should I say lack there of. Some people are luck to get 1-3 referrals a month other than get ready to be expected to cold call for the rest.
advice_to_mgmt: Read a book on how to actually manage employees. When someone hits quota for the month, be excited! Don’t drag them down with your negativity. Get a CRM from this decade.

- Recently told by WTS president that software engineering at West is "slow." This is disheartening because the Flowroute culture has thrived moving quickly and developing new technologies along the way. I see much more work to be done on fixing tech debt to integrate into the corporate atmosphere than working on products themselves or fixing tech debt for scalability or maintainability.
- Bonuses only for execs (per West policy)
- General office atmosphere has dipped in morale since acquisition.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Actively demonstrate you value culture beyond words.
- Take the time to listen to your employees.
- Plan the next software acquisition on the west coast in a way that demonstrates research of the current market and company values.

cons: Having a new C-Suite that talks out of both sides of their mouth makes effective communication impossible. One example is the CEO defending a major change to the US PTO plan, in all honesty I understand the need for the change from a financial view, but as this new plan was rolled out during an all employee meeting the CEO basically challenged anyone to a duel if they wanted to discuss the change. Employees not only saw the behavior as aggressive but even if they did have questions, who would ask him at that point?? With West being made up of so many acquisitions I am not sure it is possible for West to operate as one company. There is still way too much finger pointing and no accountability.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop asking for feedback when it falls on deaf ears, be empathetic to those down the food change who actually keep the doors of this dysfunctional company open. Throw them a thank you every once in a while, a sincere one, not during an all company meeting that employees are forced to watch on their own time because only those upper level leaders can actually spend 90 minutes on a webinar.

review_title: A great job for those who like to stick to the basics.
years_at_company: A great job for those who like to stick to the basics.
pros: You choose your hours as long as you hit 40, as a sales rep you pretty much have complete freedom with breaks and such as long as you're hitting your numbers, the job itself is easy to do and doesn't require much, great achievable bonus potential, constant opportunities for advancement, they promote from within, management is helpful and supportive but doesn't stand over your shoulder or micro-manage. Fun activities and challenges to help motivate higher metrics, you can socialize throughout the day and they encourage it as long as everyone is doing their jobs. I've worked at Alta before coming here and it's a completely different environment-- much more welcome and friendly, much more freedom.
cons: Being a call center, things change a lot, people get switched around between teams, turnover isn't the greatest so people are in and out. A bit of workplace social drama but it's easy enough to stay out of. You have to use PTO for sick days and leaving early, doctor's appointments, etc, instead of having the option to just take the missed time unpaid and save your PTO for when you actually need it, but I understand that because to qualify for benefits you need to consistently hit 40 hours. But if you miss so much as fifteen minutes and don't make up the time later in the week, your PTO gets applied to it. In the same area, when I originally interviewed, PTO was awarded on anniversaries for staying with the company, which was a huge factor in why I decided to work here. This reward system has since been removed, so there is less PTO potential throughout the year. There is no food or blankets allowed on the floor for sanitary reasons but it's kind of a pain to have to sit in the breakroom any time you need to snack on something when you could be getting work done and munching between dials. The pay is decent but it's mid-range and raises aren't really a thing unless you get promoted or you've been there for many years.
advice_to_mgmt: PTO is a huge motivator in a call-center environment -- regardless of how fun and engaging you guys really do make the job, working in a call center is an emotionally taxing and draining job, no matter what. That isn't West's fault, but having more days off, in my opinion, reduces turnover and gives us much needed time away from the hundreds of dials to not-so-happy people we make every day. It was a huge aspect of the interview process that your HR people emphasized as a benefit, and now it's being changed in what I interpret as kind of a shady way. I get that you have numbers to hit with the clients' expectations, but losing more people and having to fill empty cubicles because they're tired of making dials day in and day out with no time off isn't going to help your numbers. This is a fantastic company with a wonderful HR team that knows what they're doing, understands the work and doesn't forget what it was like to be on the floor. Don't lose that aspect.

pros: Gartner MQ (which West is now slipping out of), partnership with Cisco (also degrading), employees (oh wait, most of the good ones ran far away)

advice_to_mgmt: Learn how to take care of your employees. Unhappy employees=unhappy customers.

pros: The list of pros are dwindling fast as the Wisconsin business unit is lost in a downward spiral with shortsighted, reactive, leadership desperately trying to navigate a corporate culture that does not want or value them. The benefits were adequate and the work life balance was strong, they have some good people in middle management that make it a place that makes you WANT to succeed.
cons: Increased pressure to hit profit margins are crushing the soul of this company as it continually impacts its biggest resource- its people. As the company sinks into trouble its most key executives continue to thrive while their support staff becomes over-taxed and/or eliminated one after another. A recent loss of one of its 2 largest clients resulted in a lateral-ish advancement of an executive responsible while an entire workforce of 250+ entire offices, and 3 senior management positions were eliminated. This is a sign of the scramble they are in. The executives will care for them selves while they can- but they know its sinking.
advice_to_mgmt: Leave the spoke and wheel model, do not retract into a mega center model. Stay the course with small manageable spaces in markets you can actually compete in or your doors will close by 2020 in my opinion. Your current CEO is making public remarks about wanting you gone and cut rate call center giants are backing out of purchase agreements for you. This will not end well.

review_title: Good if you really need a job to pay bills
years_at_company: Good if you really need a job to pay bills
pros: I think the only pros at this job is that you get pto and benefits right away, and your co workers that you sit by
cons: I would say this whole job is a con.. they don’t train you very well, they throw you on the phones right after they switch you to another segment during training, tell you to forget everything. You have no idea what your doing because you practically are training yourself. You have to follow these intense rules that even though your with someone and the door is already open you still have to scan your badge. They rush you during training where it’s hard to even keep up because they rush you so much or they forget to train you on things . You never see your specific manager. All the higher-ups are always switching around you switch desks all the time. And the pay is low. They tell you your starting out at one rate of pay but yet others get to start out a higher pay during the interview they tell you everyone starts out the same. But everyone starts out different. So I wouldn’t advise this job to anyone.
advice_to_mgmt: Better training would actually keep people around.

pros: They give you lots of PTO
cons: Terrible company, awful pay, no respect

pros: Direct management is very helpful and flexible
cons: not sure what the direction of the company's future is

pros: Fun working environment and contests
cons: Hours are based on call volume

pros: Company culture, leadership, company goals
cons: Training was limited for a new hire

pros: Flexible work environment and good training courses
cons: Legacy Technologies and Very low pay

review_title: Everything has changed. Awful place to work now
years_at_company: Everything has changed. Awful place to work now
pros: None that I can see anymore
cons: Everything. Horrible Senior Management, horrible pay, benefits were just cut to nothing, nothing good to say. Don't work here!
advice_to_mgmt: Know your location culture...this is your undoing. Management in Omaha just cut everyone's vacation benefits if you've worked here more than 5 years. Most people lost 10 days plus of their vacation package. First they took away the beloved cafeteria as a cost savings measure...then everything started to go with it. Our latest round of layoffs cut a bunch of people. Management, you are giving nobody that's been here more than 5 years anything to stick around for. Most people I talk to are openly planning on leaving as soon as they can, that includes core people that this company can't live without.

pros: There has been an influx of positive reviews in the last week. It very suspicious since there hasn’t been that many in the last 6 months but suddenly executives are posting reviews. West is currently going thru a restructuring and laying off people left and right. There have been hundreds laid off don’t believe these reviews from the last week.
cons: Terrible company and Apollo group is running it into the ground. Tons of layoffs and they have almost zero direction. They are just trying to bleed the company so they can try and sell it.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop lying to your employees about what is going on. You need to re-evaluate what you are doing in tech. You are getting bad advice and the path you are choosing is going to be a disaster because you don’t understand what we do at it’s core. Don’t be fooled by the smoke in mirrors from some technical divisions. You are being misinformed about the tech stack and what it can do. You need to stop and do a deep dive before you try and combine all these platforms and realize you are going to lose customers.

review_title: Steady Work but Poor Training Policies
years_at_company: Steady Work but Poor Training Policies
pros: Steady Work, Good Computer Systems
cons: Trainers defensive, unwilling to answer questions. Supervisors too busy to be able to answer same questions.
advice_to_mgmt: Do not require a person to spend unnecessary time listening to calls, etc., when they ask a simple procedural question.

pros: Large company provides potential for movement across many business areas.
cons: Not a real solid place to call work home. Things were always 'up in the air' as far as projects and even company direction.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire some great, progressive, business leaders.

pros:
+ PE-Backed company with strong growth aspirations
+ Transformation story in the making (telecom dinosaur to cool communications tech provider)
+ Strong senior leadership team that promotes a meritocracy culture
+ Aggressive growth through acquisition with the opportunity to define your own career oportunities
cons:
+ Some culture clash between new management style and lifers; company is still working to find it's unique culture and combined voice
+ Moving from a holding company to an operating company is challenging
advice_to_mgmt: + Continue to hone West's go-to-market message. What is West? What is the one sentence every employee should know about who we are and what we do, whether they are in sales or facilities, sit in New York or Omaha or sell Unified Communications or Digital Media products?

pros: Great benefits, good hours, competitive hourly pay and bonus structure, friendly people, family atmosphere, people who care about your goals and ambitions and help you achieve them.
cons: Not too many downsides in my opinion other than the lack of communication sometimes between management and employee.
advice_to_mgmt: Be more open and honest with communicating the changes and such for the company and also provide more gratitude for the hard work that some of us are here to actually do. Not all of us are here to just collect a pay check.

pros: Generous PTO after 1 year, good coworkers.
cons: Dysfunctional leadership, bedbugs in the office, unrealistic goals. Even with a good client relationship it still felt like no one knew what was going on.
advice_to_mgmt: Act like leaders and not babysitters. Easily the least professional environment you can imagine, but it is a call center.

pros: Innovative , great technology, great employees.
cons: No real direction. Is chaotic and no accountability. No regards for the customers or employees well being
advice_to_mgmt: Get it together have a solid plan. Stop buying companies and focus on having a real strategy with what you have.

pros: Access to a lot of their other company resources
cons: All about profitability so cutbacks that make day to day worse aren't fun.

pros: Good benefits, laid-back atmosphere, good hours
cons: Low pay, few opportunities for advancement

pros: Great flex options with shift hours for work/life balance. We are provided all the tools and guidance needed to be successful in sales. Career path options are able to be seen as West prefers to promote from within over hire leaders from the outside. If you take to the guidance and use the tools you will be successful. If you let your leader know you are interested in advancement, they will help you to develop as a leader or for the next position.
cons: Some of the sales goals can seem lofty, unless you have plan for attainment.

pros: When I leave at the end of the day
cons: Benefits, compensation, equipment, training, vague about role during interview

pros: Great benefits, fast paced, challenging
cons:
Lack of respect from
Leadership
advice_to_mgmt: Be open and don’t form opinion of people so quickly

review_title: Warm crowd. You'll never feel stranger!
years_at_company: Warm crowd. You'll never feel stranger!
pros:
The working environment is very positive and salary is competitive as well.

Employees, most especially the management team are easy to transact with.
cons:
Benefits - leaves, hmo, bonuses/merit increases, employee engagement et al.

It's still within the industry standard though but a bit behind compared to what other BPO companies are offering.

pros: West is a company led by exceptional leaders who truly are looking to create a positive, successful, collaborative environment for the company and each individual employee to succeed.
cons: You must be willing to work hard and be a team player. Not really a con, but no real cons to report.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to do what you are doing !

review_title: Great Company & Excellent Benefits – PTO in your first year!
years_at_company: Great Company & Excellent Benefits – PTO in your first year!
pros: Great co-workers and clients who truly appreciate what we do for their business. Rewards, bonuses, recognition and PTO are just a few of the Pros.
cons: Things change often – but for anyone who loves working with people that can pivot and adapt they will consider this a Pro!
advice_to_mgmt: Work at home is a great way to attract and retain talent.

review_title: Lots of Great Opportunities for Growth!
years_at_company: Lots of Great Opportunities for Growth!
pros: Fast paced growth company with lots of opportunity. Leader in communication market place with a remarkable client list. Strong management team.
cons: The pace of change might not be for everyone.

pros: Transformational Company, with focus on acquisitions provides employees the opportunity to make a significant impact to the future performance of the firm.
cons: Companies in transformation can often be difficult to navigate, but with the right leadership, talent, collaboration and determination it can be done.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to stay focused on the transformation path - the benefits will be recognized over time. The journey has just begun.

pros: I have a long tenure with West and have seen the company go through many changes. While change is never easy, it's often necessary. I believe that the most recent changes in leadership, structure and strategy sets West up for a successful future. There is a great deal of opportunity to make your mark for someone who is willing to work hard. The West leadership team believes in transparency and communication.
cons: As West works through it's transformation, you must be willing to work in a fast paced, changing, agile work environment. This isn't a con, but a change in how West has done business in the past.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to communicate with the employees. The additional avenues of exposure (CEO round tables, weekly Management updates, employee newsletter, videos, etc.) have greatly helped!

pros: Time with family, leadership in areas is very family oriented and understands the family time, and the company is very generous with PTO.
cons: It's a job, the company is transitioning to new platforms and new leadership so there is uncertainty.

pros: Decent pay, good hours, no weekends, some perks.
cons: West is a corporate prostitute through and through. They'll sacrifice customer service and future profit for today's bottom line. That is how they lost their rear and had to sell out to an investment group and go private. They ended up hosing a lot of people in the process... customers and employees alike.
advice_to_mgmt: Most managers here are redundant and unnecessary and have no clue how to do the actual WORK that's done by the regular employees. Waaay too many mid-level managers who contribute nothing.

pros: West has gone through some changes in the last two years. The company was a public company and kind of a sleeping giant with a lot of unlocked potential. It was purchased by one the best private equity funds out there (Apollo), and new management is committed to unlocking that value. Apollo knows how to make money. West is destined for great things. Unfortunately, corporate change is hard, and some people from the sleepy past will be unhappy with change. But West is fund dynamic place to work with new, smart, committed leadership.
cons: Culture change is hard and some folks (past and present employees) will complain. You can see that in some of these Glassdoor reviews. But what that means for prospective employees is *Opportunity*. But dealing with naysayers can be difficult at times.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep driving how the message of the story of new West and the bright future ahead.

pros:
New Management Team is making a positive difference to the culture of West. For those that do not have their minds closed to change, great things are happening inside of this company.

The CEO genuinely cares about making this a great company and believes that starts with employees who love coming to work each day. He is extremely approachable and open to feedback and suggestions from employees at every level.
cons: I have none at this time.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep moving in the direction you are headed and do not let negative feedback from people who hate change bring you down.

pros: West provides great opportunities to learn and achieve at an accelerated pace in every department. These opportunities require swift change, implementation, and flexibility. It is a fast paced environment that requires teamwork, trust, and a high ethical standard for successful employment.
cons: An employee must enjoy the culture and the pace of change required to be successful. If an employee is not flexible to change and/or dislikes a fast paced environment, the pace can be overwhelming.

pros: New Leadership is a breath of fresh air offering new ideas, communication and transparency. Work from home flexibility is key.
cons: If you are hesitant to change, West may not be the right place for you.

pros: Wesr has become a place of growth and opportunity!
cons: Your going to have to work hard
advice_to_mgmt: Spread the word about the new Wesr!

pros: Executive team is stellar and involves and welcomes all employee feedback and interaction. Team environment! Good to employees! Employment opportunities!
cons: No cons to mention to date
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work!
